speaker: Outstanding Directorial Achievement in Comedy Series
text: James Burrows, Bill Carroll, Brian James Ellis, Steven Pomeroy, Rick Beren  EMMY

speaker: Outstanding Directing
text: James Burrows
prevSpeaker: Outstanding Directorial Achievement in Comedy Series
nextSpeaker: Outstanding Writing for a Comedy Series

speaker: Outstanding Writing for a Comedy Series
text: David Angell, Peter Casey, David Lee  * * *  ## Cast List [_in order of appearance_]    FRASIER CRANE..........................................KELSEY GRAMMER  ROZ DOYLE.................................................PERI GILPIN  NILES CRANE.........................................DAVID HYDE PIERCE  WAITRESS.................................................GINA RAVARRA  MARTIN CRANE.............................................JOHN MAHONEY  DELIVERYMAN.............................................CLETO AUGUSTO  EDDIE...........................................................MOOSE  DAPHNE MOON...............................................JANE LEEVES   * * *  ## Guest Callers    GRIFFIN DUNNE as Russell LINDA HAMILTON as Claire   * * *  ## Transcript {simon aw}     **THE JOB**  _Scene One - KACL The Frasier Crane Show.  Dr. Frasier Crane, the host, is at his console, admonishing a caller; Roz Doyle, his call-screener, is in her booth._

speaker: Frasier
text: [_firmly_] Listen to yourself, Bob!  You follow her to work, you eavesdrop on her calls, you open her mail.  The minute you started doing these things, the relationship was _over_! [_polite_] Thank you for your call. [_presses a button; to Roz_] Roz, I think we have time for one more?
prevSpeaker: Outstanding Writing for a Comedy Series

speaker: Roz
text: Yes, Dr Crane.  On line four, we have Russell from Kirkland.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_presses a button_] Hello, Russell.  This is Dr Frasier Crane; I'm listening.

speaker: Russell
text: [_v.o._] Well, I've been feeling sort of, uh, you know, depressed lately. [_Roz looks at the clock_] My life's not going anywhere and-and, er, it's not that bad.  It's just the same old apartment, same old job...

speaker: Frasier
text: Er, Russell, we're just about at the end of our hour.  Let me see if I can cut to the chase by using myself as an example.  Six months ago, I was living in Boston.  My wife had left me, which was very painful.  Then she came back to me, which was excruciating.  On top of that, my practice had grown stagnant, and my social life consisted of... hanging around a bar night after night.  You see, I was clinging to a life that wasn't working anymore, and I knew I had to do something, anything.  So, I ended the marriage once and for all, packed up my things, and moved back here to my hometown of Seattle.  Go Seahawks! [_laughs_] I took action, Russell.  And you can, too.  Move, change, do something; if it's a mistake, do something else.  Will you do that, Russell?  Will you?  Russell...? [_to Roz_] I think we lost him.

speaker: Roz
text: No, we cut to the news thirty seconds ago.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_annoyed; rips off his headphones_] Oh, for crying out loud! I finally bare my soul to all of Seattle, and they're listening to Chopper Dave's "Rush-Hour Round-Up!"

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, the rest of the show was pretty good. [_Roz says nothing_] It was a, a good show, wasn't it?

speaker: Roz
text: [_tears him a piece of notepaper_] Here, your brother called.

speaker: Frasier
text: Roz, in the trade we call that "avoidance."  Don't change the subject, tell me what you think.

speaker: Roz
text: [_points at her console_] Did I ever tell you what this little button does?

speaker: Frasier
text: I am not a piece of Lalique.  I can handle criticism.  How was I today?

speaker: Roz
text: [_turns her chair to face him_] Let's see... you dropped two commercials, you left a total of twenty-eight seconds of dead air, you scrambled the station's call letters, you spilled yogurt on the control board, and you kept referring to Jerry - with the identity crisis - as "Jeff."  _Frasier considers the criticism.  He decides to handle it with avoidance._

speaker: Frasier
text: [_takes the notepaper_] You say my brother called...

speaker: Roz
text: Mmm-hmm.  _Frasier leaves.  FADE OUT_  **THE BROTHER**  _Scene Two - Cafe Nervosa Frasier is at the bar, reading a menu.  Niles Crane, his younger brother, is standing next to him recounting a story._

speaker: Niles
text: So I said to the gardener, "Yoshi, I do not want a Zen garden in my backyard.  If I want to rake gravel every ten minutes to maintain my inner harmony, I'll move to Yokohama."  Well, this offends him, so he starts pulling up Maris's prized Camellias. Well, I couldn't stand for that, so I marched right into the morning room and locked the door until he cooled down.  _Frasier has been nodding his head, but he has obviously not been listening._

speaker: Niles
text: Tell me you would have handled it differently, Frasier.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_looks up_] Oh, I'm sorry, Niles, I didn't realise you'd stopped talking.

speaker: Niles
text: You haven't heard a word I said.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh Niles, you're a psychiatrist - you know what it's like to listen to people prattling on endlessly about their mundane lives.

speaker: Niles
text: _Touch e._  And on that subject, I heard your show today.

speaker: Frasier
text: And?

speaker: Niles
text: You know what I think about pop psychiatry.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, I know what you think about everything.  When was the last time you had an unexpressed thought?

speaker: Niles
text: I'm having one now.  _They share a chuckle.  The waitress behind the bar comes over. Niles takes his briefcase off the bar and goes to an empty table nearby._

speaker: Waitress
text: You guys ready?

speaker: Frasier
text: Two cafe latte supremos.  _He goes to the table, and watches Niles obsessively wipe his chair dowm with a handkerchief.  Niles offers the handkerchief to Frasier._

speaker: Frasier
text: No, thank you.

speaker: Niles
text: So, Frasier.  How are you doing on your own?

speaker: Frasier
text: I'm fine.  I love my new life.  I love the solitude. I miss Frederick like the dickens, of course.  You know, he's quite a boy.  He's playing goalie on the peewee soccer team now.  Ha, he's a chip off the old block!

speaker: Niles
text: You hated sports.

speaker: Frasier
text: So does he! [_laughs_] The fresh air's good for him.

speaker: Niles
text: [_laughs_] Oh well, this has been fun, Frasier, but... we have a problem, and that's why I thought we should talk.

speaker: Frasier
text: Is it Dad?

speaker: Niles
text: Afraid so.  One of his old buddies from the police force called this morning.  He went over to see him, and found him on the bathroom floor.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh my God!

speaker: Niles
text: No, it's okay, he's fine.

speaker: Frasier
text: What, his hip again?

speaker: Niles
text: Frasier, I don't think he can live alone anymore.

speaker: Frasier
text: What can we do?

speaker: Niles
text: Well, I know this isn't going to be anyone's favourite solution, [_opens his briefcase_] but I took the liberty of checking out a few convalescent homes for him. [_puts some brochures on the table_]

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh Niles, a home?  He's still a young man!

speaker: Niles
text: Well, you certainly can't take care of him - you're just getting your new life together.

speaker: Frasier
text: Absolutely.  Besides, we were never simpatico.

speaker: Niles
text: Of course, I can't take care of him.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh yes, yes, of course, of course... why?

speaker: Niles
text: Because Dad doesn't get along with Maris.

speaker: Frasier
text: Who does?

speaker: Niles
text: I thought you liked my Maris!

speaker: Frasier
text: I do.  I... I like her from a distance.  You know, the way you like the sun.  Maris is like the sun.  Except without the warmth.

speaker: Niles
text: Well then, we're agreed about what to do with Dad. [_reads a brochure_] "Golden Acres: We Care So You Don't Have To."

speaker: Frasier
text: It says that?

speaker: Niles
text: Well, it might as well!

speaker: Frasier
text: Alright, I'll make up the spare bedroom.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, you're a good son, Frasier.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh God, I am, aren't I?  _Downcast, he cradles his head in one hand.  The waitress arrives with their coffees._

speaker: Waitress
text: Two cafe supremos.  Anything to eat?

speaker: Frasier
text: [_depressed_] No.  I seem to have lost my appetite.

speaker: Niles
text: [_perky_] I'll have a large piece of cheesecake!  _Frasier glares at Niles.  FADE TO:_  **THE FATHER**  [_N.B. The Apartment set was built on the same soundstage at Paramount Studios that housed the set of "Cheers."_] _Frasier is playing the piano.  The doorbell rings; he stops playing, shuts the keyboard lid, and disconsolately trudges to the door.  Just before opening it, he casts a melodramatic gaze over his apartment: the last moment of solitude.  Then, he opens the door._

speaker: Frasier
text: [_upbeat_] Hi! [_laughs_]

speaker: Niles
text: We finally made it!  _Martin Crane, their father, hobbles in on a cane.  He does not look at all enthusiastic._

speaker: Frasier
text: Ah Dad, Dad, welcome to your new home! [_hugs Martin_] Gee, you look great!

speaker: Martin
text: Don't B.S. me, I do not look great.  I spent Monday on the bathroom floor.  You can still see the tile marks on my face. [_sits on the couch_]

speaker: Niles
text: [_to Frasier_] Gives you some idea about the ride over in the car. [_puts down the suitcases_]

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, er, here we are...  _Martin, who has propped his leg on a table, accidentally kicks a glass ornament off of the side; Frasier catches it._

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, rest assured the refrigerator is stocked with your favourite beer, Ballantines, [_places the glass ornament on a small folding table_] and we've got plenty of hot links and coleslaw...

speaker: Niles
text: Mmm!

speaker: Frasier
text: And I just rented a Charles Bronson movie for later!

speaker: Martin
text: Let's cut the "Welcome To Camp Crane" speech.  We all know why I'm here.  Your old man can't be left alone for ten minutes without falling on his ass, and Frasier got stuck with me.  Isn't that right?

speaker: Frasier/Niles
text: [_laughing_] No, no!

speaker: Frasier
text: I want you here!  It'll give us a chance to get reacquainted!

speaker: Martin
text: That implies we were acquainted at one point.

speaker: Niles
text: Well listen, [_picks up the suitcases_] why don't I take Dad's things into his new bachelor quarters so you two scoundrels can plan some hijinks!

speaker: Martin
text: I think that wife of his is finally driving him nutso.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, we Crane boys sure know how to marry. [_goes to the kitchen_] Let me get you a beer, Dad.  So, ah, what do you think of what I've done with the place, eh? [_returns and sits on the couch, handing a beer to Martin_] You know, every item here was carefully selected.  This lamp by Corbusier, the chair by Eames, and this couch is an exact replica of the one Coco Chanel had in her Paris _atelier_.

speaker: Martin
text: Nothing matches.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, it's a, it's a style of decorating, it's called "eclectic." [_off Martin's look_] Well, the theory behind it is, if you've got really fine pieces of furniture, it doesn't matter if they match - they will go together.

speaker: Martin
text: It's your money.  _The doorbell rings.  Frasier gets up; as he goes to the door, he gestures at the view of the Seattle skyline offered by the balcony windows._

speaker: Frasier
text: Dad, what do you think of the view?  Hey, that's the Space Needle there!

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, thanks for pointing that out.  Being born and raised here, I never would have known.  _Frasier chafes briefly; then, he opens the door to a delivery man, who has with him an old, battered, and aesthetically unpleasing Barcalounger._

speaker: Man
text: Delivery for Martin Crane.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, in here! [_gets up_]

speaker: Man
text: Coming through!  _He quickly wheels The Armchair into the room.  Frasier and Niles (who has returned) look on aghast at this latest addition to the apartment's luxury furnishings._

speaker: Frasier
text: Excuse me, excuse me, wait a minute-

speaker: Man
text: Where d'you want it?

speaker: Martin
text: Where's the TV?

speaker: Niles
text: [_points_] It's in that credenza.

speaker: Martin
text: Point it at that thing.

speaker: Man
text: [_sees a designer chair in the way_] What about this chair?

speaker: Niles
text: Ah, the chair?  Here, let me get it out of your way.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_shocked_] Niles, Niles, Niles, be careful with that, that's a Wassily!  _The delivery man leaves.  Martin sits in The Armchair, newly installed as the centrepiece of the apartment._

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh look, Dad, as dear as I'm sure this, this piece is to you I, I just don't think it goes with anything here!

speaker: Martin
text: I know, it's eclectic!  _He reclines, knocking over the small folding table; Frasier rescues the glass ornament again, and rights the table._

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles, Niles, will you help me out here?

speaker: Martin
text: Ah, you're gonna have to run an extension cord over here so I can plug in the vibrating part.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh yes, that will be the crowning touch.

speaker: Niles
text: Well, now that you two are settled in, I've got to run. I'm late for my dysfunctional family seminar.

speaker: Niles
text: Dad, have you mentioned Eddie yet?

speaker: Frasier
text: [_horrified_] Eddie?

speaker: Niles
text: Ta-ta! [_closes the door_]

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh no, Dad, no, no!  Not Eddie!

speaker: Martin
text: But he's my best friend!  Get me my beer, would you?

speaker: Frasier
text: [_fetches the beer_] But he's weird!  He gives me the creeps! All he does is stare at me.

speaker: Martin
text: Ah, it's just your imagination.

speaker: Frasier
text: No Dad, no!  No, I'm sorry, but I am putting my foot down. Eddie is NOT moving in here. **EDDIE**  _Scene Four - Apartment -Night The lights are off.  Martin is in his chair, eating a hot link and watching the Charles Bronson movie; sounds of mindless violence can be heard emanating from the TV.  The camera pans over to the couch, where an uncomfortable-looking Frasier is seated.  Perched next to Frasier is Eddie - a wire-haired Jack Russell terrier.  Eddie stares at Frasier.  End of Act One.  Act Two.  Scene Five - Cafe Nervosa. Niles has just been served his coffee; Frasier rushes in._

speaker: Frasier
text: [_anxious_] Niles, there you are!  I'm sorry I'm late; just as I was leaving, Dad decided to cook lunch by the glow of a small kitchen fire!  Oh Niles, this last week with Dad, it's, it's been a living hell!  When I'm there, I feel like my territory's being violated; when I'm not, I'm worried about what he's up to.  Look at me, [_shows Niles his shaky hands_] I'm a nervous wreck!  I've got to do something to calm down. [_goes to the bar_] Double espresso, please!  Niles, you don't still have the brochures from those rest homes, do you?

speaker: Niles
text: Of course I do.  Don't forget, Maris is five years older than I am.  But you really think that's necessary?

speaker: Frasier
text: I'm afraid I do.  I don't have my life anymore.  Tuesday night I gave up my tickets to the theatre, Wednesday it was the symphony... [_gets his coffee_]

speaker: Niles
text: That reminds me, weren't you going to the opera on Friday?

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, here. [_hands him some tickets_]

speaker: Niles
text: Thank you.

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles, you don't suppose there's a chance that you and Maris could...

speaker: Niles
text: Funny you should mention that.  Maris and I were just discussing this.  We feel we should do more to share the responsibility.

speaker: Frasier
text: You mean you'd take him in?

speaker: Niles
text: [_laughs incredulously_] Dear God, no!  But we would be willing to help you pay for a home care worker.

speaker: Frasier
text: A what?

speaker: Niles
text: You know, someone who cooks and cleans and can help Dad with his physical therapy.

speaker: Frasier
text: These angels exist?

speaker: Niles
text: I know of an agency - let me arrange for them to send a few people over to meet with you.

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles, I can't thank you enough!  I, I, I feel this overwhelming urge to hug you!

speaker: Niles
text: Remember what Mom always said: "A handshake is as good as a hug."

speaker: Frasier
text: Wise woman.  _They shake hands.  FADE TO:_  **THE HOME CARE SPECIALIST**  _Scene Six - Apartment A woman is standing in the hallway, talking to Frasier._

speaker: Frasier
text: I have never been more impressed with a human being in my life!  _He closes the door on her.  Cut to inside the apartment.  Martin is in The Armchair; Eddie is on the couch._

speaker: Frasier
text: [_angry_] Now what was wrong with that one?!

speaker: Martin
text: She was casing the joint.

speaker: Frasier
text: "Casing the joint!"  She spent two years with Mother Teresa!

speaker: Martin
text: Well, if I were Mother Teresa, I'd check my jewellery box!

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, this is the last one.  Can you please try to keep an open mind?  _He opens the door to Daphne Moon, a British woman in her twenties. She is adjusting her bra as Frasier opens the door._

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh!  Hello - caught me with my hand in the biscuit tin! [_takes her hand out and shakes Frasier's_] I'm Daphne, Daphne Moon.

speaker: Frasier
text: Frasier Crane.  Please come in.

speaker: Daphne
text: Thank you. [_enters_]

speaker: Frasier
text: Er, this is my father, Martin Crane.  Dad, this is Daphne Moon.

speaker: Daphne
text: Nice to meet you. [_sees Eddie_] Oh, and who might this be?

speaker: Frasier
text: [_darkly_] That is Eddie.

speaker: Martin
text: I call him "Eddie Spaghetti."

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh, he likes pasta?

speaker: Martin
text: No, he has worms.

speaker: Frasier
text: Er, have a seat, Miss Moon.

speaker: Daphne
text: Daphne.  Thank you. [_sees The Armchair and pats it_] Oh, will you look at that.  What a comfy chair!  It's like I always say, start with a good piece and replace the rest when you can afford it.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes.  Well, er, perhaps you should start by telling us a little bit about yourself, Miss Moon.

speaker: Daphne
text: Well, I'm originally from Manchester, England...

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh really, did you hear that, Dad?

speaker: Martin
text: I'm three feet away.  There's nothing wrong with my hearing.  _Daphne begins to take all sorts of things out of her bag: a brush, a glass, a sponge - and finally, a piece of paper which she hands to Frasier._

speaker: Daphne
text: I've only been in the U.S. for a few months, but I have quite an extensive background in home care and physical therapy, as you can see from my resume.  I... [_suddenly turns toward Martin_] You were a policeman, weren't you?

speaker: Martin
text: Yeah - how'd you know?

speaker: Daphne
text: I must confess - I'm a bit psychic.  It's nothing big, just little things I sense about people.  I mean, it's not like I can pick the lottery.  If I could, I wouldn't be talking to the likes of you two, now would I? [_laughs_]

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes.  Perhaps I should describe the duties around here. You would be responsible for...

speaker: Daphne
text: [_suddenly turns towards Frasier_] Oh, wait a minute, I'm getting something on you... you're a florist!

speaker: Frasier
text: No, I'm a psychiatrist.

speaker: Daphne
text: Well, it comes and goes. [_puts her things back into her bag_] Usually, it's strongest during my time of the month.  Oh, I guess I let a little secret out there, didn't I?

speaker: Frasier
text: It's safe with us.  Well, Miss Moon, I think we've learned just about all we need to know about you, and a dash extra! [_goes to the door_]

speaker: Daphne
text: [_waves her arms at Eddie_] You're a dog, aren't you?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, we'll, er, we'll be calling you, Miss Moon. [_goes for the door handle_]

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, why wait? [_to Daphne_] You've got the job!

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh, wonderful!

speaker: Frasier
text: [_annoyed_] Er excuse me, excuse me, aren't you just forgetting a little something here?  Don't you think we should talk about this in private?

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh, of course you should; I completely understand. [_she stands up and shoulders her bag_] I'll just pop into the loo - you do have one, don't you?

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes.

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh, I love America...

speaker: Frasier
text: Dad, what do you think you're doing?

speaker: Martin
text: You wanted me to pick one, I picked one.

speaker: Frasier
text: But she's a kook!  I don't like her!

speaker: Martin
text: Well, what difference does it make to you?  She's only gonna be here when you're not.

speaker: Frasier
text: Then... what's my problem? [_laughs_] Daphne!

speaker: Frasier
text: You've been retained.

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh, wonderful!  I had a premonition.

speaker: Frasier
text: _Quelle surprise._

speaker: Daphne
text: I'll move my things in tomorrow.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, move in?  Oh, I'm sorry, there must be some misunderstanding.  Er, this isn't a live-in position.

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh, dear.  Well the lady at the agency-

speaker: Frasier
text: The lady at the agency was wrong; this is just a part-time position.  I'm, I'm afraid it just won't work out.

speaker: Martin
text: [_gets up_] Hold on there, Frasier, let's talk about this!

speaker: Frasier
text: Dad, there's nothing to discuss!

speaker: Daphne
text: You two should talk about this.  I'll just pop back in here and enjoy some more of your African erotic art.

speaker: Frasier
text: Daphne, Daphne - I think it would be best if you leave.

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh well, alright then. [_goes to leave_]

speaker: Frasier
text: Don't be alarmed.  We'll contact you.  If not by telephone then, er, through the toaster.

speaker: Frasier
text: Dad, I'm not having another person living in this house!

speaker: Martin
text: Give me one good reason why not!

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, for one thing, there's no room for her!

speaker: Martin
text: What about that room right across the hall from mine?

speaker: Frasier
text: My study?  You expect me to give up my study - the place where I read, where I do my most profound thinking?

speaker: Martin
text: Ah, use the can like the rest of the world!  You'll adjust!

speaker: Frasier
text: [_angry_] I don't want to adjust!  I've done enough adjusting! I'm in a new city, I've got a new job, I'm separated from my little boy, which in itself is enough to drive me nuts.  And now my father and his dog are living with me!  Well, that's enough on my plate, thank you.  The whole idea of getting somebody in here was to help ease my burden, not to add to it!

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, do you hear that, Eddie?  We're a burden.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh Dad, Dad, you're, you're twisting my words!  I meant burden in its most positive sense!

speaker: Martin
text: As in, "Gee, what a lovely burden?"

speaker: Frasier
text: Something like that, yes!

speaker: Martin
text: Well, you're not the only one who got screwed here, you know. Two years ago I'm sailing toward retirement and some punk robbing a convenience store puts a bullet in my hip.  Next thing you know, I'm trading in my golf clubs for one of these. [_shakes his cane_] Well, I had plans too, you know!  And this may come as a shock to you, sonny boy, but one of them wasn't living with you.

speaker: Frasier
text: I'm just trying to do the right thing, here.  I'm trying to be the good son.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, don't worry, son.  After I'm gone you can live guilt-free, knowing you've done right by your pop.

speaker: Frasier
text: You think that's what this is about, guilt?

speaker: Martin
text: Isn't it?

speaker: Frasier
text: Of course it is!  But the point is, I did it!  I took you in! And I've got news for you - I wanted to do it! [_on the verge of tears_] Because you're my father.  And how do you repay me? Ever since you've moved in here it's been a snide comment about this or a smart little put-down about that. [_grabs his coat and goes to the door_] Well, I've done my best to make a home here for you, and once, just once, would it have killed you to say "thank you?"  One lousy "thank you?"

speaker: Martin
text: [_to Eddie_] Come on, Eddie, it's past your dinner time.

speaker: Frasier
text: I'm going out.  _He leaves.  FADE TO:_  **LUPE VELEZ**  _Scene Seven - KACL The corridor outside Frasier's studio.  Frasier tears into the hallway and rushes into the booth.  Inside the studio, Roz is in her booth. Frasier slams the door and drops into his chair._

speaker: Frasier
text: They have got to move the bathroom closer to the studio!

speaker: Frasier
text: [_polite_] We'll be right back after these messages. [_off air_] Can't I put that on tape?!

speaker: Roz
text: What's eating you?

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, I'm sorry.  It's just this thing with my father and this, this person he wants to hire.  I thought I'd started my life with a clean slate.  I had picture of what it was going to be like, and then, I don't know...

speaker: Roz
text: Ever heard of Lupe Velez?

speaker: Frasier
text: Who?

speaker: Roz
text: Lupe Velez - the movie star in the '30s.  Well, her career hit the skids, so she decided she'd make one final stab at immortality.  She figured if she couldn't be remembered for her movies, she'd be remembered for the way she died.  And all Lupe wanted was to be remembered.  So, she plans this lavish suicide - flowers, candles, silk sheets, white satin gown, full hair and makeup, the works.  She takes the overdose of pills, lays on the bed, and imagines how beautiful she's going to look on the front page of tomorrow's newspaper.  Unfortunately, the pills don't sit well with the enchilada combo plate she sadly chose as her last meal.  She stumbles to the bathroom, trips and goes head-first into the toilet, and that's how they found her.

speaker: Frasier
text: Is there a reason you're telling me this story?

speaker: Roz
text: Yes.  Even though things may not happen like we planned, they can work out anyway.

speaker: Frasier
text: Remind me again how it worked for Lupe, last seen with her head in the toilet?

speaker: Roz
text: All she wanted was to be remembered. [_beat_] Will you ever forget that story?  [_N.B. In fact, the Los Angeles newspapers reported Lupe's suicide as though she had carried it off as planned; the sordid details were kept quiet and for a long time existed only as rumor._]  _She returns to her booth and cues him.  He puts his headphones on; everything from now onwards is on the air._

speaker: Frasier
text: We're back.  Roz, who's our next caller?

speaker: Roz
text: We have Martin on line one.  He's having a problem with his son.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_presses a button_] Hello, Martin.  This is Dr. Frasier Crane; I'm listening.

speaker: Martin
text: [_v.o._] I'm a first-time caller.

speaker: Frasier
text: Welcome to the show.  How can I help you?

speaker: Martin
text: I've just moved in with my son and er, it ain't working. There's a lot of tension between us.

speaker: Frasier
text: I can imagine.  Why do you think that's so?

speaker: Martin
text: I guess I didn't see he had a whole new life planned for himself, and I kinda got in the way.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, these things are a two-way street.  Perhaps your son wasn't sensitive enough to see how your life was changing.

speaker: Martin
text: [_suddenly loud_] You got that right!  I've been telling him that since I got there!

speaker: Frasier
text: I'm sure he appreciated your candour.

speaker: Martin
text: Well, maybe sometimes I oughta just learn how to keep my trap shut.

speaker: Frasier
text: That's good advice for us all.  Anything else?

speaker: Martin
text: Yeah, I'm worried my son doesn't know that I really appreciate what he's doing for me.

speaker: Frasier
text: Why don't you tell him?

speaker: Martin
text: Well, you know how it is with fathers and sons, it... I have trouble saying that stuff.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, if it helps, I suspect your son already knows how you feel.  Is that all?

speaker: Martin
text: Yeah, I guess that's it.  Thank you, Dr Crane.

speaker: Frasier
text: My pleasure, Martin.

speaker: Martin
text: [_suddenly loud again_] Did you hear what I said?  I said "thank you!"

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, I heard.

speaker: Roz
text: Dr Crane, we have Claire on line four.  She's having a problem getting over a relationship.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_presses a button_] Hello, Claire.  I'm listening.

speaker: Claire
text: [_distraught_] I'm a, well, I'm a mess!  Eight months ago my boyfriend and I broke up, and I just can't get over it.  The pain isn't going away.  It's almost like I'm in mourning or something.

speaker: Frasier
text: Claire, you are in mourning.  But you're not mourning the loss of your boyfriend.  You're mourning the loss of what you thought your life was going to be.  Let it go.  Things don't always work out how you planned; that's not necessarily bad.  Things have a way of working out anyway. [_pause_] Have you ever heard of Lupe Velez?
